Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in New Zealand
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Brian Steidinger of Indiana University Bloomington to conduct a research project, entitled "Investigating novel defenses of New Zealand conifers towards exploitative fungi," during the summer of 2012 at Landcare Research in Lincoln, Christchurch. The host scientist is Ian Dickie.

The Intellectual Merit of the research project is to uncover unique adaptations of Southern hemisphere conifers (Podocarpaceae) that may allow them to segregate and sanction exploitative fungal partners upon whom they rely for soil nutrients. Field studies are being conducted in collaboration with scientists in New Zealand who collaborate with Maori Iwis (self-governing communities) who collect samples on protected land. This research explores the efficacy of plant defenses against exploitative fungi in natural conditions - investigations that complement ongoing laboratory work on the same subject. In addition to studying the ecology and physiology of plant defenses, this project provides a learning experience for the Fellow on the economic and cultural value of NZ conifers, which are used for timber and steeped in native mythology.

Broader Impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
My research assessed whether a group of New Zealand trees have a unique root anatomy that provides protection against fungal root parasites. It is currently unknown how plants are able to prevent exploitation by fungi, particularly when parasitic individuals mimmic host-beneficial ones. To determine this, I collected samples of the root systems of trees with different types of root-anatomy from across Peel Forest on the South Island of New Zealand. In addition, I conducted experimental work in a greenhouse that suggests that modular root anatomies, where fungi are hosted inside compact nodules, tend to exclude parasitic individuals. I am currently working to characterize the species inside the root samples from Peel Forest to determine if root nodules are also good at excluding parasites in the field. This work involves extracting and amplifying fungal DNA, sequencing segments of this DNA, and comparing it to public data-bases to identify these sequences to species whenever possible. This work involves training undergraduate volunteers on all of the relevant molecular methods, which can be applied to a wide range of ecological problems later in their careers. This research is ongoing and aimed at determining if specific root anatomies can provide trees with protection against parasites under natural conditions. Funding format he NSF EAPSI provided me with the means to connect experimental and field work to determine the basis for plant defense against parasitic root fungi.
